0: You can use <1>, <2>, ... to reference parameters that usually appear in answers for this service. References to the database are possible as well, e.g. <summary_0a>.

chat.name: Chat/smalltalk
chat.desc: Use this command to define a simple reply to any input.
chat.help:
Example:

When I say ...
What did the Buddhist say to the hot dog vendor?

the assistant does ...
Chat/smalltalk

and says ... (reply):
Make me one with everything.

open_link.name: Open link/website
open_link.desc: Use this command to open a website or any URL.
open_link.help:
Example:

When I say ...
Open the SEPIA homepage

the assistant does ...
Open link/website

with URL ... (url):
https://sepia-framework.github.io

and says ... (answer_set):
Here is my homepage.

0:
Use an URL relative to the client, to your local server or any public resource, e.g.:

img/icon.png

http://[sepia-server-ip]:20726/assist/files/images/cards/link.png

https://sepia-framework.github.io/img/logo.png

music_radio.name: Open music stream
music_radio.desc: Use this command to start/stop a radio station, play a radio with a certain genre or start an audio stream (URL).
music_radio.help:
Example:

When I say ...
Play my station

the assistant does ...
Open music stream

Radio station ... (radio_station):
EgoFM Pure

music.name: Search/play specific music
music.desc: Use this command to search music by song, artist, title etc. or play specific content of a supported service.
music.help:
Example:

When I say ...
Play music by Queen

the assistant does ...
Search/play specific music

Music service:
YouTube

Playlist name:
Queen Greatest Hits

3: Song named Castles made of Sand
from the album A Kind of Magic

sentence_connect.name: Execute command(s)
sentence_connect.desc:
Use this command to define an alias for one or more other commands. If you define more than one sentence (seperated by '.') they will be called one after the other (if the client supports it!). 
					This command supports 5 special flexible input parameters: <var1> ... <var5>, see example 2. 
					Each 'var' represents exactly one word, consecutive 'var' are combined to one parameter (e.g. you need '<var1> <var1> <var1>' to match 'Statue of Liberty'), see example 3. 
					Note: you cannot use sentences that you've previously defined yourself.
sentence_connect.help:
Example 1:

When I say ...
Morning briefing

the assistant does ...
Execute command(s)

using these sentences ... (sentences):
Start radio You FM just music. Open the tech news. How is the weather.

and says ... (reply):
Here is your morning briefing.

Example 2:

When I say ...
Show me <var1> by <var2>

the assistant does ...
Execute command(s)

using these sentences ... (sentences):
Search videos of <var2> <var1>.

and says ... (reply):
Searching videos.

Example 3:

When I say ...
Show me information about the <var1> <var1> <var1>

the assistant does ...
Execute command(s)

using these sentences ... (sentences):
What is <var1>. Where is <var1>.

and says ... (reply):
Searching information.

all: Info: This command supports 5 special flexible input parameters: <var1> ... <var5>. See command info for a full explanation.
1: Good morning && Weather in Berlin && Tech news
3: Good morning. Show me the weather in Berlin. Show me tech news.

smartdevice.name: Control smart home device
smartdevice.desc:
Use this command to create specific actions for smart (home) devices. Usually the parameters expect certain, predefined types (see example 1) but 
					you can use the 'i_raw' modifier to use natural language or even create new types on-the-fly using JSON (see example 2).
smartdevice.help:
Example 1:

When I say ...
Let there be light

the assistant does ...
Control smart home device

Smart device (smart_device):
<light>;;Lamp 1

Room (room):
<bedroom>

Action (action):
<set>

Value (smart_device_value):
<percent>;;70

Example 2:

When I say ...
Red!

the assistant does ...
Control smart home device

Smart device (smart_device):
<i_raw>RGB Lamp 1

Room (room):
{"value":"party_room", "value_local":"Party room", "index":"1"}

Value (smart_device_value):
{"value":"[255,0,0]", "type":"color"}

Example 3:

When I say ...
Where is mom?

the assistant does ...
Control smart home device

Smart device (smart_device):
{"value": "sensor", "value_local": "Mom", "found": "mom", "index": 1}

Action (action):
<show>

Custom answer(s):
Mom is <3>.

client_controls.name: Execute a client control function
client_controls.desc: Use this command to call a client control function like 'set sound volume' or 'open settings'. You can also call external tools like CLEXI (clexi) or a SEPIA Mesh-Node (meshNode) with specific data directly from this client.
client_controls.help:
Example 1:

When I say ...
Rock!

the assistant does ...
Execute a client control function

Action (action):
<set>

Function (client_fun):
<volume>

Generic data (data):
11

Example 2:

When I say ...
More Rock

the assistant does ...
Execute a client control function

Function (client_fun):
<media>

Media controls (media_controls):
<next>

Example 3:

When I say ...
Call my node plugin

the assistant does ...
Execute a client control function

Action (action):
<on>

Function (client_fun):
<meshNode>

Generic data (data):
{ "value": { "url": "http://localhost:20780", "plugin": "RuntimePlugin", "data": {"command": ["echo", "test"] } } }

Example 4:

When I say ...
Broadcast hello with CLEXI

the assistant does ...
Execute a client control function

Action (action):
<on>

Function (client_fun):
<clexi>

Additional data (data):
{ "value": { "xtension": "clexi-broadcaster", "data": { "text": "Hello", "sender": "Me" } } }

platform_controls.name: Execute platform specific actions
platform_controls.desc:
Use this command to create a single sentence that triggers different client actions for each device ID or platform type (e.g. call Intent in Android (type=androidActivity) and URL in browser client (type=url)). 
					Note: The device ID has highest priority, only if no device ID is given or no match is found the platform specific function will be called.
platform_controls.help:
Example 1:

When I say ...
Play Paradise City

the assistant does ...
Execute platform specific actions

Actions for specific device IDs (device_fun):
{ "value": { "a1": {"type": "androidActivity", "data": {"action": "android.media.action.MEDIA_PLAY_FROM_SEARCH", "extras": {"query": "Paradise City"} }} } }

Example 2:

When I say ...
Start Paradise City

the assistant does ...
Execute platform specific actions

Android specific Intent or URL (android_fun):
{ "value": {"type": "androidActivity", "data": {"action": "android.media.action.MEDIA_PLAY_FROM_SEARCH", "extras": {"query": "Paradise City"} } } }

Browser specific function or URL (browser_fun):
{ "value": {"type": "url", "data": {"url": "spotify:track:3YBZIN3rekqsKxbJc9FZko:play"} } }

parameters.name: Browser specific function or URL (browserIntent, url)

frame_control.name: Control custom frame
frame_control.desc: Use this command to control a custom frame (open/close/set data) if the client supports it. Custom frames are code pieces (usually mini HTML pages) that can be started/stopped, hook into the normal even cycle (input-response-action) and temporarily add additonal functionality to the client.
frame_control.help:
Example:

When I say ...
Open my demo controls panel

the assistant does ...
Control custom frame

Path to frame file (URL):
<assist_server>/views/demo-view.html

Action (action):
<on>

Frame data (JSON string):
{"data": {"my-info": "cool"}}

and says ... (reply):
Here is your view.

Example 2:

When I say ...
_demo_frame_ Select TEST

the assistant does ...
Control custom frame

Action (action):
<set>

Frame data (JSON string):
{"functionName": "test", "data": "my_data"}

and says ... (reply):
Selecting TEST.

mesh_node_plugin.name: Call SEPIA Mesh-Node plugin
mesh_node_plugin.desc: Use this command to call a SEPIA Mesh-Node plugin via the SEPIA server. In contrast to the client-controls version this command is secured by your SEPIA account and evaluated by the server which enables some extra features. Note that the given URL referes to a path relative to the server as well and can be an IP inside your private home network where your SEPIA server is located. You can refer to results of the Mesh-Node plugin call inside your success or fail answers. To do this use the variable <result_KEY> where 'KEY' refers to a data field in your plugin result data, e.g. 'hello' in the 'HelloPlugin' example.
mesh_node_plugin.help:
Example:

When I say ...
Test the hello plugin

the assistant does ...
Call SEPIA Mesh-Node plugin

Mesh-Node URL (node_url):
http://localhost:20780

Name of plugin (node_plugin_name):
HelloPlugin

JSON string sent to plugin (node_plugin_data):
{ "value": {"name":"Boss"} }

Success answer (reply_success):
Ok I understood <result_hello>

Fail answer (reply_fail):
Sorry I could not get a result
